_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response: Farmers Coop of Tappen is committed to providing a safe area free of accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. Health, Safety and Environmental compliance are fundamental parts of Farmers Coop of Tappen's commitment to the local area. Federal, State and Local laws are to be adhered to and are to implement appropiate controls to prevent accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release were to occur, the facility would respond by working with the Local Emergency Planning Committee and other authorities to control and mitigate the release and minimize the impact of the release to the area and to the general public.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled: Anhydrous Ammonia storage and distribution for use as a fertilizer on local crop production.



Contract temporary seasonal labor is used for maintance and for filling of nurse tanks.

Contract Labor is required to attend saftey and handling training annually.



Farmers Coop of Tappen does not own Nurse Tanks.



Farmers Coop of Tappen keeps inventory of anhydrous ammonia at minimal levels in the off season. (typically August through May is off season)



The following sections briefly describe the facility's release prevention program.



1)Safety Information: The facility was designed and constructed in accordance with applicable Federal and State Regulations. 



2)Hazard Review: Facility is reviewed for hazards associated with handling and storage of anhydrous ammonia. Any problems identified during the review are addressed in a timely manner.



3) Training: Saftey and Handling of Anhydrous ammonia training for contract labor is to be attended anually.



4)Maintenance: The facility inspects equipment, hoses, and piping periodically. Any probems are addressed in a timely manner.



5) Compliance Audits: As required by the RMP rule, compliance audits will be performed at least once every three(3)years. The audit will be conducted

by a person knowledgeable in the safe handling and storage of anhydrous ammonia. Corrective actions required as a result of each compliance audit will be performed promptly.



Five-Year Accident History: There has been no accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in the past five(5)years that caused deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor, to our knowledge, resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, property damage or environmental damage.



Emergency Response Program: In the event of an emergency, the facility will notify the local fire department and other emergency responders and request that they respond to the emergency.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety: There are no specific anhydrous ammonia safety changes planned at this time. However, if safety improvement is identified, changes will be made in a timely manner. Periodic inspections are performed to assess the safety of the facility.
